content.description: An excellent start on thin slab gives way to easier moves.
content.location: This is the left route on Zuma West.

content.description:
Clip the first 2 bolts of

Secret Significance

, then veer right towards the last bolt below an obvious crack (which takes great gear). Fire off a very fun, but stout sequence, then head left to the anchors.

It is not the best route to toprope as the climber could pendulum quite a bit.
content.location:
On Zuma's main wall, this route shares the same start and anchors as

Secret Significance

.

content.description:
This is a bouldery, sustained face climb on small features. The beginning is the crux. It shares anchors with

Perpetual Motion

and

Deceiving

.
content.location: On the main wall of Zuma, this is the middle line of the toprope face.

content.description: Sunshine Slab is a cool slab route that slowly ramps up in difficulty. The final move to the anchors is the crux but can be managed with good footwork.
content.location: On the far right of the main Zuma Rock. look for the small cairned trail on your left while heading right at the base of the wall.

content.description:
Secret Significance is a great beginner climb with some tricky moves that will make you think. In the past, some used the large rock up top to tie on webbing, but if you have enough webbing, a tree may be better.

Now, this has 4 bolts and chains for anchors.

If you climb up the right wall, this climb becomes a 5.10+ called Zoomer.
content.protection:
Rope and some long webbing.

Now, this has 4 bolts and anchor chains.
content.location: It is right of the main Zuma Rock.

content.description: This is a fun and funky mixed route with great rests. Work up the slab with high steps clipping bolts as you go. Trend right up the huge, sidewalk-esque ramp, and enter the corner (crux) plugging gear up to the anchors.
content.location:
This is the first line left of

Secret Significance

. Look for the distinct orange streaked corner up high.

content.description: Raindrop Slab looks deceptively easy from the bottom, but some technique is needed to keep it chill. It eases up for the second half.
content.location: From the trail, head left along the wall. You'll reach a left-facing dihedral. To the immediate left of this is a bolted, low angle slab.

content.description: This ascends thin sloping cracks all the way up.  The crux is at the first few moves.
content.protection: A top rope can be set up to a bolt at the top and a small tree as a backup.
content.location: It is the rightmost route on the wall with the face.

content.description:
Face It! climbs a nice not-quite-vertical finger crack, a feature that is otherwise rare for Summit County. Sticking to the crack brings it to a solid 5.11, but using the shallow features on the face brings down the difficulty.

Begin up easy and chunky terrain to the crack. The protection before this point is pretty slim, but the the climbing is very easy. The protection in the crack is most excellent. Figure it out, clear an easy bulge up top, and head to the anchors.

I hope you brought small hands!
content.protection:
Gear up to 0.5". This shares anchors with

Corners 101

.
content.location: It is on the far right end of the main Zuma Wall. You cannot see the east-facing crack from the main area, so just keep walking climber's right until you get to a dirty chossy gully, and turn around.

content.description:
Deceiving ascends very thin, quartzite holds up a bare face. This is a pretty desperate climb. It shares anchors with

Perpetual Motion

and

Unknown 12

.
content.protection: A toprope. This has its own anchors now
content.location: On the main wall of Zuma, this is the furthest climb on the left of the toprope face.

content.description: Corners 102 is very easy and blocky.
content.location:
It is just past

Face It!

content.description:
This route is truly a crash course in cracky dihedrals and right angles. Work up the face to the orange blocks, and go up whatever looks the coolest to you (from my understanding there are many variations). Be prepared for some contortionist antics.

NOTE: this is not the best route to TR - it meanders, and the anchors are far from the edge, so your rope and climber may suffer damage.
content.location: It ascends the weird looking, orange, blocky corner on the far right side of the wall.

content.description:
This is a sport route that shares an anchor with

Australian Two Step

.
content.location:
This is to the right

Australian Two Step

on Zuma West.
